newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks rebound to 4th straight record close.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks rebound to 4th straight record close.

text.p: Mexican stocks recovered from an early bout of profit-taking to chalk up their fourth record close in a row on Thursday after bargain-hunters stepped into the market in late trade, dealers and analysts said.
"Such selling as there was withered away. Once profit-taking had taken prices down, buyers came back from the sidelines," a technical analyst said.
The leading IPC share index .MXX ended up 20.37 points, or 0.57 percent, at 3,578.34. Volume .TV.MX was moderate at 84.1 million shares traded.
Some dealers said demand for stocks was fueled by foreign investors taking positions ahead of the weekend and brokers picking up less marketable stocks at bargain prices.
"After many blue chips had soared to resistance, investors turned to less marketable and bargain stocks, such as Camesa," a floor trader said.
Other dealers noted that sharp gains on Wall Street -- 1.16 percent to 6,625.67 points -- also bolstered the bolsa.
Analysts felt the bourse still had upside potential.
"The market has woken up with a vengeance, and is still sending buy signals," the technical analyst said.
"Any corrections will only be to consolidate the upward trend towards 3,600 points," he added.
Despite the record close, the broad market was mixed. Of a total of 102 stocks traded, sliders outnumbered gainers by 44 to 41.
Debt-stricken holding company Sidek headed the gainers, up ten centavos to 90 centavos, but after a minimal last-minute cross trade, dealers said.
Financial group Serfin followed Sidek, up 33 centavos to 3.13 pesos, after what analysts said was a technical breakthrough at 2.90 pesos.
Another gainer, steelmaker Ahmsa gained 88 centavos to 16.50 pesos following a long-term buy recommendation from Merrill Lynch, traders said.
Auto parts maker Iasasa fell four centavos to 29 centavos at the head of the sliders' list on persistent financial woes, traders said.
Bus and truck manufacturer, Dina, followed Iasasa, falling 25 centavos to 4.20 pesos after what traders said was a volatile session for its ADRs on Wall Street, which ended off 1/8 at 2-1/4.
